Let $A\subseteq \mathbb{N}$ be an additive basis (of any finite order) such that $\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert=o(N)$. Is it true that\[\lim_{N\to \infty}\frac{\lvert (A+A)\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert}{\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert}=\infty?\]



The answer is no, and a counterexample was provided by Turj\'{a}nyi \cite{Tu84}. This was generalised (to the replacement of $A+A$ by the $h$-fold sumset $hA$ for any $h\geq 2$) by Ruzsa and Turj\'{a}nyi \cite{RT85}. Ruzsa and Turj\'{a}nyi do prove (under the same hypotheses) that\[\lim_{N\to \infty}\frac{\lvert (A+A+A)\cap \{1,\ldots,3N\}\rvert}{\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert}=\infty,\]and conjecture that the same should be true with $(A+A)\cap \{1,\ldots,2N\}$ in the numerator.




References


[RT85] Ruzsa, I. Z. and Turj\'{a}nyi, S., A note on additive bases of integers. Publ. Math. Debrecen (1985), 101-104.

[Tu84] Turj\'{a}nyi, S., A note on basis sequences. Topics in classical number theory, Vol. I, II (Budapest, 1981) (1984), 1571-1576.
